g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
the importance of economic growth including
climate change itself, pointing to the relationship between economic development and climate resilience
powered technologies such as electric vehicles
Yet, others argue that the character
of social and economic development produced by the nature of capitalist society
wo major implications of the very close link between climate change and
development as outlined above. The first is that the choice of development paths made by countries and
regions have significant consequences for GHG emissions and efforts to combat cli
Chapters 2, 3, 4, 5, and 14). The second is that climate mitigation at local, national and global level
cannot be effectively achieved by a narrow focus on ‘climate
specific’ sectors, actors and policies; but
r attention to the mix of development choices and the resulting
As a key staple of IPCC reports and global climate policy landscape
al. 2019; van Vuuren et al. 2017; IPCC 2014b, 2007; see also Chapter 2)
between development paths, climate change and emission stabilisation (see
The impact of climate change in limiting wellbeing is most acutely felt by the world’s poorest people,
communities, and nations, who have the smallest carbon footprint, constrained capacity to respond and
. The wide variation in the contribution to, and impact of
climate change within and across co
untries makes equity, inequality, justice, and poverty eradication,
inescapable aspects of the relationship between sustainable development and climate change
et al. 2017; Okereke and Coventry 2016; Bos and Gupta 2019; Klinsky et al. 2017; Baarsch et al. 2020;
Kayal et al. 2019; Diffenbaugh and Burke 2019)
. This underpins the conclusion as commonly expressed
that climate action needs to be pursued in the context of sustainable development, equity and poverty
(Burton et al. 2001; Smit et al. 2001; Klinsky and Winkler 2014; Tschakert and Olsson
Concepts and frameworks for integrating climate mitigation and development:
development can be seen as a meta framework for integrating climate action
(Antal and Van Den Bergh 2016; Casadio Tarabusi and Guarini
Fundamentally, the concept of sustainable development underscores the interlinkages and
interdependence of human and natural systems
need to balance economic, social, and
environmental (including climate pollution) aspects in development planning and processes
espite the appeal of the concept, tensions remain over the interpretation and practical application, with
acute disagreements regarding what the balancing entails in real life, how to measure wel
goals to set, and the means through which such goals might be pursued
et al. 2019; Okereke and Massaquoi 2017; UNEP 2018b; Arrow et al. 2011; Dasgupta et al. 2015;
Sugiawan et al. 2019; Haberl et al. 2019)
Moreover, countries differ enormously in their respective situation regarding their d
a condition which affects their capability, goals, priorities and approach to the pursuit of sustainability
Mejía et al. 2018; Okereke et al. 2019; Shi et al. 2016)
Most of the literature recognises that
ustainable development with its emphasis on integrating social, economic and
environmental goals, provides a more comprehensive approach to the pursuit of planetary health and
